awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase II: Center for the Integration of Composites into Infrastructure (CICI)
awd_abstract_narration:
Efficient infrastructure systems such as highways, bridges, buildings, pipelines, flood control systems and utilities are all necessary for a healthy economy and comfortable standard of living. Concrete, steel and timber are the backbones of physical infrastructure. High strength polymer composites have been used for aerospace structures for about five decades and their use in civil infrastructure spans about 20 years. To accelerate the adoption of polymer composites into infrastructure, the NSF I/UCRC Center of the Integration of Composites into Infrastructure (CICI) was established as a joint effort of West Virginia University (WVU), North Carolina State University (NCSU) and the University of Miami. Recently, NSF has awarded a travel grant to establish an additional CICI site at Nanjing University of Technology in China. The NSF I/UCRC program brings together universities, private companies and government agencies together to leverage the research dollars for all parties by engaging in highly cooperative research. CICI's work with civil infrastructure has a tremendous effect on daily life, thus the Nation as a whole benefits as composite and hybrid materials lead to infrastructure systems of higher safety, shorter construction times and longer life spans at a reduced overall cost and improved labor productivity with the creation of new and higher skilled job opportunities. Member companies and end users benefit from the interaction with others in their field including highly trained students, with over 100 students expected to pass through CICI in the next 5 years. CICI is prolific technology transfer machine, exceeding the output for most I/UCRCs through the publishing of journal articles and conference presentations to promote the scientific research and knowledge dissemination. 

Broadly speaking, the technical focus of CICI can be broken into four different areas. Initially, fundamental research projects are undertaken to broaden the knowledge base on infrastructure composites. This includes lifecycle performance, aging studies, evaluation of bond strength within a composite and as a substrate, and many others. From this on-going research, products are being developed that can be mass-implemented in infrastructure markets, including innovative hollow core or basalt fiber FRP rebar, waterway products that are noncorrosive or fabric reinforced cementitious composites for masonry wall strengthening and many others. The implementation of these products is the next focus area and is primarily accomplished through the development of codes and specifications. CICI has worked on the ASCE LRFD pultruded GFRP composites code, ASTM specifications, ACI building design and construction codes, the International Code Council and IIFC. Finally, CICI has an evaluation component based on IAB member feedback to ensure the composites that are implemented in the field are performing as designed as a part of our long-term performance program. Thus, through research, development, implementation and evaluation, CICI is involved in all facets of composite product evolution.

por.por_cntn:
This Phase II NSF IUCRC on the integration of composites into infrastructure (CICI) began in 2014 as a collaborative effort between West Virginia University as the lead site, the University of Miami, and NC State University. The University of Texas at Arlington joined CICI in 2015.

The primary goal of the Center was to accelerate the adoption of fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) composites into civil infrastructure through joint research programs between the university sites in collaboration with the composites and construction industries. The Center's goal was achieved by: (1) conducting fundamental research that benefits both the composites and construction industries, and end users; (2) developing durable, cost-effective composite products that represent large market opportunities; (3) working collaboratively with industry partners to implement the research and development efforts primarily through standard and specification development; and (4) undertaking evaluation of FRP composites during manufacturing and field application.

Cost-effective, reliable and resilient infrastructure systems are necessary for a healthy economy and comfortable standard of living. However, the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) has been consistently grading the condition of infrastructure in the United States within the D+ range. This less than satisfactory grade is largely attributed to the funding gap, estimated at $2-3 trillion, between revenue and infrastructure needs for the period of 2016-2025. For example, the United States has more than 614,000 bridges with approximately 40% of them in service for more than 50 years. Approximately 56,000 of the nation's bridges were categorized as structurally deficient in 2016 carrying approximately 188 million crossings each day. The use of advanced composites will play an integral role in enhancing the current condition of critical civil infrastructure systems, and in developing more durable infrastructure in the future - enabling improved economic sustainability and societal resilience in the United States and worldwide.

During the project period the NC State University site collaborated with eleven different industy partners, ranging from FRP producers to end users, a state agency, a professional trade organization, and an internationally based company. More than $800,000 was generated in membership fees, and tens of thousands of dollars worth of full-scale test specimens were donated in-kind to support the experimental programs of the Center projects. The membership fees and research projects supported the completion of eight PhD graduates, and four research based Masters graduates. Five undergraduate research assistants also supported the research programs. More than 25 archival journal articles and more than 35 refereed conference papers have been published to-date. More refereed articles are still being finalized and submitted for review based on outcomes of completed research projects. Outcomes of the research projects have been included in national design guides and codes, and have influenced material and construction specifications. The most notable technology transfer success story at NC State University involves the development of an FRP retrofit system that has already been installed on three bridges in North Carolina. The bridges would have been load posted, or closed, following the biannual inspection resulting in lengthy detours with significant direct and indirect economic cost and disruption to the local community. The installed retrofit has allowed the bridges to remain open and in-service until replacement bridges can be budgeted and constructed. One of the bridges has remained in-service for more than two years and the refrofit continues to perform as expected. The developed retrofit system was recognized with an ASCE Innovation Award in 2019.
